articles.headline: A Mistaken News Report Hurts United
articles.snippet: Shares of United Airlines lost nearly all their value when a false bankruptcy rumor swept financial markets.
articles.abstract: Shares of United Airlines lost nearly all their value when a false bankruptcy rumor swept financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: How jittery are investors about airline stocks these days? Just ask United.

articles.headline: No One Convicted of Terror Plot to Bomb Planes
articles.snippet: A jury convicted three of eight defendants of lesser charges in a case involving an alleged plot to blow up airliners, but failed to reach verdicts on other charges.
articles.abstract: A jury convicted three of eight defendants of lesser charges in a case involving an alleged plot to blow up airliners, but failed to reach verdicts on other charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  A lengthy trial centering on what Scotland Yard called a plot to blow up trans-Atlantic airliners ended Monday when the jury convicted three of eight defendants of conspiracy to commit murder.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Elaine Sciolino

articles.headline: Antitrust Document Exposes Rift
articles.snippet: The Justice Department has issued antitrust guidelines for corporate monopolies, but the Federal Trade Commission, which shares enforcement of antitrust law, refuses to endorse them.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department has issued antitrust guidelines for corporate monopolies, but the Federal Trade Commission, which shares enforcement of antitrust law, refuses to endorse them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department laid out a broad policy on antitrust enforcement on Monday that drew an unusually sharp rebuke from three federal trade commissioners, who said it would protect monopolies from prosecution.

articles.headline: Popularity of a Hallucinogen May Thwart Its Medical Uses
articles.snippet: The use of Salvia divinorum, a potent hallucinogenic herb, was once limited to revelation seekers in Mexico. Now, the drug is available legally across the U.S.
articles.abstract: The use of Salvia divinorum, a potent hallucinogenic herb, was once limited to revelation seekers in Mexico. Now, the drug is available legally across the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS  With a friend videotaping, 27-year-old Christopher Lenzini of Dallas took a hit of Salvia divinorum, regarded as the world’s most potent hallucinogenic herb, and soon began to imagine, he said, that he was in a boat with little green men. Mr. Lenzini quickly collapsed to the floor and dissolved into convulsive laughter.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and Brent McDonald

articles.headline: Straining to Reach Money Goal, Obama Presses Donors
articles.snippet: Bypassing public financing may not provide Barack Obama’s campaign with the commanding financial advantage many predicted.
articles.abstract: Bypassing public financing may not provide Barack Obama’s campaign with the commanding financial advantage many predicted.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of record-breaking fund-raising, a new sense of urgency in Senator Barack Obama’s fund-raising team is palpable as the full weight of the campaign’s decision to bypass public financing for the general election is suddenly upon it.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Rescue of Mortgage Giants Displays Paulson’s Clout
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary has led President Bush where he would not usually go: into government intervention in the markets.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary has led President Bush where he would not usually go: into government intervention in the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush may be the nation’s first M.B.A. president, but when Mr. Bush and a small coterie of advisers met in the Oval Office last week to complete their plan to rescue the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, there was no question who was in charge.

articles.headline: Paulson’s Itchy Finger, on the Trigger of a Bazooka
articles.snippet: Once the Treasury secretary mentioned the possibility that the Bush administration might take over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, he virtually guaranteed that was exactly what would happen.
articles.abstract: Once the Treasury secretary mentioned the possibility that the Bush administration might take over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, he virtually guaranteed that was exactly what would happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If you’ve got a bazooka, and people know you’ve got it, you may not have to take it out.”

articles.headline: Reinventing Mortgage Giants: A Big Rebuild or a Teardown?
articles.snippet: Policy makers and Congress have begun an epic fight over how to restructure the companies after the crisis.
articles.abstract: Policy makers and Congress have begun an epic fight over how to restructure the companies after the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A day after the government seized control of the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, policy makers and Congress began what promises to be an epic political fight over how to revamp the companies once the current crisis ends.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Who Else Can Pile On for a Federal Rescue?
articles.snippet: Many in the financial industry say a more formal debate is needed to set criteria to guide decisions on future requests for help from individual companies or industries.
articles.abstract: Many in the financial industry say a more formal debate is needed to set criteria to guide decisions on future requests for help from individual companies or industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the definition of companies that are “too big to fail” getting broader? Or are some industries simply more important than others?
